Tasks.Task Description: Gather detailed requirements for the Azure Peering Service, including bandwidth, latency, and redundancy needs. Identify the applications and services that will use the service.
Design the network architecture to integrate Azure Peering Service with existing on-premises and Azure networks. Include considerations for redundancy and failover.
Choose a connectivity provider that supports Azure Peering Service and meets the required Service Level Agreement (SLA) for bandwidth and latency.
Request the LOA from Microsoft for Azure Peering Service. This document authorizes the connectivity provider to provision the connection.
Create and configure the Azure Peering Service in the Azure portal or using Azure CLI/PowerShell. Ensure the service is provisioned in multiple locations for redundancy.
Submit the LOA to the chosen connectivity provider to initiate the provisioning of the physical connection.
Set up peering policies, including route filters and traffic prioritization, to ensure optimal performance and security.
Enable required security measures, such as encryption and access control policies, to secure the peering connections.
Perform thorough testing of the connectivity, including failover scenarios, throughput tests, and latency measurements to ensure the network meets the required specifications.
Set up monitoring and alerting using Azure Monitor and Network Watcher. Configure alerts for connection status, performance metrics, and security events.
Document the network architecture, configurations, and operational procedures. Ensure the operations team is trained on managing and troubleshooting the setup.
Ensure the setup meets all regulatory compliance requirements. Implement regular auditing procedures to verify compliance and security postures.
Use Azure Monitor to continuously track the performance metrics of Azure Peering Service, including latency, packet loss, and jitter. Investigate anomalies promptly.
Regularly verify the connectivity and performance of the Internet Service Provider (ISP) linked to Azure Peering Service. Ensure compliance with SLA agreements.
Review BGP route advertisements to ensure proper routing and avoid misconfigurations that could impact connectivity.
Conduct regular audits of security configurations, including encryption settings and access controls, to ensure compliance with organizational policies.
Test failover mechanisms to ensure redundancy and high availability in case of ISP outages or service disruptions.
Review and update ISP peering policies to align with changes in network architecture or business requirements.
Perform regular compliance checks to ensure Azure Peering Service adheres to regulatory and industry standards.
Conduct drills to prepare the team for potential security incidents or service outages. Ensure familiarity with response protocols.
Evaluate the SLA performance of the ISP providing Azure Peering Service. Address any deviations from agreed metrics.
Develop and execute plans for Azure Peering Service upgrades or expansions as needed. Ensure minimal disruption during these activities.
Ensure the operations team participates in regular training to stay updated with new Azure Peering Service features and best practices.
Regularly back up configurations of network devices and settings related to Azure Peering Service. Ensure secure storage of backups for restoration purposes.
Collect and analyze user feedback regarding Azure Peering Service performance and reliability. Implement continuous improvements based on this feedback.
